_link.title: I can explain that nuclear energy results from the conversion of mass to energy

toLevel2.stem: According to Einstein's famous equation, what is the relationship between mass and energy?
options: E = mc² (energy equals mass times the speed of light squared)
E = mv (energy equals mass times velocity)
E = ma (energy equals mass times acceleration)
E = mgh (energy equals mass times gravity times height)
toLevel2.explanation: Einstein's equation E = mc² shows that mass and energy are equivalent, with energy equal to mass multiplied by the speed of light squared.

toLevel2.stem: What happens to mass during nuclear fission and fusion reactions?
options: A small amount of mass is converted into energy
toLevel2.explanation: In both fission and fusion, a small amount of mass is converted into energy according to E = mc², releasing enormous amounts of energy.

toLevel2.stem: Why do nuclear fuels contain much more energy per kilogram than chemical fuels?
options: Nuclear reactions convert mass to energy while chemical reactions only rearrange electrons
Nuclear fuels burn at higher temperatures
Chemical fuels lose energy through radiation
Nuclear reactions are slower and more efficient
toLevel2.explanation: Nuclear reactions involve mass-to-energy conversion via E = mc², while chemical reactions only involve electron rearrangements without mass change.

toLevel2.stem: What does the 'c' represent in Einstein's equation E = mc²?
options: The speed of light in a vacuum
toLevel2.explanation: In E = mc², 'c' represents the speed of light in a vacuum, approximately 3 × 10⁸ m/s. This large value explains why small mass changes release huge amounts of energy.

toLevel2.stem: Which types of nuclear reactions involve mass-to-energy conversion?
toLevel2.explanation: Both nuclear fission (splitting heavy atoms) and nuclear fusion (combining light atoms) convert mass to energy according to E = mc².

toLevel2.stem: Nuclear energy is released when a small amount of [[mass]] is converted into [[energy]] according to E = mc².
toLevel2.explanation: Einstein's mass-energy equivalence shows that mass and energy are interconvertible, with nuclear reactions demonstrating this by converting mass to energy.

toLevel2.stem: In E = mc², the large value of [[c]] (the speed of light) explains why small mass changes produce [[enormous]] amounts of energy.
toLevel2.explanation: Since c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, even tiny mass losses result in very large energy releases when multiplied by c².

toLevel2.stem: The mass-energy equivalence principle forms the basis for understanding all [[nuclear]] technologies including power plants and [[weapons]].
toLevel2.explanation: E = mc² underpins all nuclear energy technologies, from peaceful power generation to nuclear weapons, explaining their enormous energy output.

toLevel2.stem: Chemical reactions also convert mass to energy, just like nuclear reactions.
toLevel2.explanation: False. Chemical reactions only rearrange electrons and do not involve measurable mass-to-energy conversion. Only nuclear reactions convert mass to energy.

toLevel2.stem: Einstein's equation E = mc² explains why nuclear fuels are millions of times more energy-dense than chemical fuels.
toLevel2.explanation: True. The mass-to-energy conversion in nuclear reactions, governed by E = mc², releases about a million times more energy per kilogram than chemical burning.

toLevel3.stem: Why is the factor c² so significant in making nuclear energy so powerful?
options: Because c² is an extremely large number (about 9 × 10¹⁶), small mass changes release huge energy
Because c² makes the reaction happen faster
Because c² determines the temperature of the reaction
Because c² controls the number of neutrons produced
toLevel3.explanation: With c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s, c² = 9 × 10¹⁶ m²/s². This enormous multiplier means tiny mass losses (grams) produce massive energy releases.

toLevel3.stem: How can the products of a nuclear reaction have less total mass than the reactants?
options: The missing mass has been converted into the kinetic energy of the products
toLevel3.explanation: The mass difference (mass defect) appears as kinetic energy of the products and as gamma radiation, in accordance with E = mc².

toLevel3.stem: In nuclear reactions, what happens to the 'lost' mass?
options: It is converted into kinetic energy and radiation
It simply disappears from the universe
toLevel3.explanation: Mass is conserved in terms of mass-energy equivalence. The missing mass appears as kinetic energy of products and gamma radiation.

toLevel3.stem: Why is mass-energy equivalence not noticeable in everyday chemical reactions?
options: The mass changes in chemical reactions are too small to measure
Chemical reactions do not follow E = mc²
Only nuclear scientists can detect mass changes
Mass-energy equivalence only applies to nuclear reactions
toLevel3.explanation: Chemical reactions involve electron rearrangements with negligible energy changes. The corresponding mass change (via E = mc²) is far too small to detect.

toLevel3.stem: What is the relationship between binding energy and mass in a nucleus?
options: Higher binding energy means lower nuclear mass due to mass-energy equivalence
Higher binding energy means higher nuclear mass
Binding energy has no effect on nuclear mass
Only unstable nuclei have binding energy
toLevel3.explanation: The binding energy holding nucleons together corresponds to a mass defect. More tightly bound nuclei have less mass than their separated constituents.

toLevel3.stem: How does the mass of a uranium nucleus compare to the sum of its individual protons and neutrons?
options: The nucleus has less mass due to binding energy
The nucleus has more mass than the individual particles
toLevel3.explanation: The nucleus has less mass than its separate nucleons because binding energy (holding them together) corresponds to a mass defect via E = mc².

toLevel3.stem: The mass difference between reactants and products is called the [[mass defect]] and is converted to [[energy]].
toLevel3.explanation: Mass defect is the difference between the mass of separate nucleons and the actual nuclear mass, representing the energy binding the nucleus together.

toLevel3.stem: Nuclear reactions release energy because the products have [[less]] mass and [[greater]] stability than the reactants.
toLevel3.explanation: Products of nuclear reactions are more stable (higher binding energy per nucleon) and thus have less mass. The mass difference becomes released energy.

toLevel3.stem: When 1 kg of uranium undergoes complete fission, only about [[1 gram]] of mass is converted to energy, releasing about [[9 × 10¹³]] joules.
toLevel3.explanation: About 0.1% of the mass is converted to energy in fission. Using E = mc², 0.001 kg × (3×10⁸)² ≈ 9 × 10¹³ joules.

toLevel3.stem: The total mass-energy of a closed system is always conserved, even in nuclear reactions.
toLevel3.explanation: True. While mass may convert to energy, the total mass-energy is conserved. The apparent mass loss appears as an equivalent amount of energy.

toLevel4.stem: If 0.1% of the mass of uranium is converted to energy during fission, how much energy is released from 1 kg of uranium?
Calculate the energy released when 1 gram of mass is completely converted to energy.
A nuclear reactor produces 1000 MW of power. How much mass is converted to energy per second?
toLevel4.explanation: Power = 10⁹ W = 10⁹ J/s. Using m = E/c²: m = 10⁹ / (9 × 10¹⁶) ≈ 1.1 × 10⁻⁸ kg = 0.011 grams per second.

toLevel4.stem: If 1 kg of coal releases about 3 × 10⁷ J when burned, how many times more energy does complete mass-to-energy conversion of 1 kg release?
toLevel4.explanation: Complete conversion: E = 1 × (3 × 10⁸)² = 9 × 10¹⁶ J. Ratio: (9 × 10¹⁶)/(3 × 10⁷) = 3 × 10⁹ (3 billion times).

toLevel4.stem: A student wants to calculate the mass equivalent of 1 joule of energy. What is the approximate answer?
toLevel4.explanation: m = E/c² = 1 / (9 × 10¹⁶) ≈ 1.1 × 10⁻¹⁷ kg. This shows why mass-energy conversion is not detectable in everyday processes.

toLevel4.stem: In the Sun, about 4 million tonnes of mass are converted to energy every second. What is the power output?
If a nuclear reaction releases 200 MeV of energy, what is the mass converted? (1 eV = 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ J)
To calculate mass from energy, rearrange E = mc² to get m = [[E/c²]], where c = [[3 × 10⁸]] m/s.
toLevel4.explanation: Rearranging E = mc² gives m = E/c². The speed of light c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s.

toLevel4.stem: A 1000 MW reactor converts approximately [[0.011 grams]] of mass to energy every [[second]].
toLevel4.explanation: 1000 MW = 10⁹ J/s. Mass per second = 10⁹ / (9 × 10¹⁶) ≈ 1.1 × 10⁻⁸ kg = 0.011 grams.

toLevel4.stem: Nuclear fission converts about [[0.1%]] of the fuel mass to energy, while fusion converts about [[0.7%]] of hydrogen mass.
toLevel4.explanation: Fission converts about 0.1% of uranium mass to energy. Fusion of hydrogen to helium converts about 0.7%, which is why fusion releases more energy per kilogram.

toLevel5.stem: Why does fusion release more energy per kilogram of fuel than fission, despite both following E = mc²?
options: Fusion converts a higher percentage of fuel mass to energy
toLevel5.explanation: Fusion converts about 0.7% of hydrogen mass to energy, while fission converts only about 0.1% of uranium mass. The percentage difference explains the energy density advantage.

toLevel5.stem: How does the binding energy curve explain where energy is released in nuclear reactions?
options: Moving toward iron from either direction releases energy due to increased binding energy per nucleon
Only heavy elements can release energy
Binding energy has no relationship to energy release
toLevel5.explanation: Iron-56 has maximum binding energy per nucleon. Light nuclei fusing or heavy nuclei splitting toward iron's mass range increase stability and release energy.

toLevel5.stem: Compare the practical implications of E = mc² for nuclear power versus nuclear weapons.
options: Both use the same principle but with different rates and control of energy release
Power plants convert more mass than weapons
The principle only applies to weapons
toLevel5.explanation: Both technologies convert mass to energy via E = mc². Power plants control the rate for sustained energy; weapons release energy explosively in microseconds.

toLevel5.stem: Why is only a tiny fraction (0.1-0.7%) of nuclear fuel mass converted to energy rather than all of it?
options: Nuclear reactions only change binding energy, not the mass of protons and neutrons themselves
Current technology cannot achieve complete conversion
Most of the mass escapes as radiation
Nuclear fuel is diluted with non-reactive material
toLevel5.explanation: Nuclear reactions rearrange nucleons into more stable configurations, releasing only the binding energy difference. Complete mass-to-energy conversion would require matter-antimatter annihilation.

toLevel5.stem: What would be required to achieve 100% mass-to-energy conversion?
options: Heating the fuel to solar temperatures
toLevel5.explanation: Only matter-antimatter annihilation converts 100% of mass to energy. Nuclear fission and fusion only convert small fractions associated with binding energy changes.

toLevel5.stem: Evaluate why Einstein's E = mc² revolutionized understanding of energy in the universe.
options: It unified the concepts of mass and energy as different forms of the same thing
It proved that energy cannot be created
It showed that mass is always conserved
toLevel5.explanation: E = mc² revealed mass-energy equivalence, showing they are interconvertible. This explained stellar energy sources and enabled nuclear technology development.

toLevel5.stem: How does mass-energy equivalence explain the source of the Sun's energy?
options: Hydrogen fusion converts 0.7% of hydrogen mass to energy, powering the Sun for billions of years
The Sun burns hydrogen like a chemical fire
Gravitational collapse alone produces the Sun's energy
The Sun uses nuclear fission of heavy elements
toLevel5.explanation: Solar fusion converts 600 million tonnes of hydrogen to helium per second, with 4 million tonnes becoming energy via E = mc², enough to sustain the Sun for billions of years.

toLevel5.stem: Why is it scientifically incorrect to say that mass is 'destroyed' in nuclear reactions?
options: Mass-energy is conserved; mass is converted to an equivalent amount of energy
Mass cannot change in any process
Nuclear reactions create mass, not destroy it
Only chemical reactions can change mass
toLevel5.explanation: Total mass-energy is always conserved. Mass isn't destroyed but transforms into energy. The reaction products plus released energy equal the initial mass-energy.

toLevel5.stem: Complete mass-to-energy conversion requires [[matter-antimatter]] annihilation, which converts [[100%]] of mass to energy.
toLevel5.explanation: When matter meets antimatter, both are completely converted to energy (gamma rays). This is the only process achieving complete mass-to-energy conversion.

toLevel5.stem: The Sun converts [[4 million tonnes]] of mass to energy every [[second]], following Einstein's equation.
toLevel5.explanation: The Sun's power output of 3.8 × 10²⁶ W corresponds to mass loss of about 4 × 10⁹ kg/s, sustained by its enormous hydrogen supply.
